section.title: Modulation
section.p: At its simplest, modulationmodulationdefinition of is a change of key that happens within a composition. In popular music, the change of key will often be called a key changekey change instead of a modulation. Those who study classical music theory typically reserve the term modulation for the slower and more subtle change of key that occurs in many classical pieces, although there are similarities between key change in popular music and the classical music term direct modulation, which we will study later in this chapter.

section.p: Notice that this cadential formula establishes a key more strongly than the simple of an authentic cadence. This means there will be ambiguity between a tonicization and a short modulation ending in an authentic cadence, especially in music with fast harmonic rhythm, like Bach chorales (usually in quarternote harmonic rhythm).

section.p: To determine pivot chords and the new key, listen to the music to hear the cadence in the new key, then work backward from the cadence to see if the dominant in the new key was approached by pre-dominant chords ( or ) in the new key. Then, analyze from the beginning of the phrase until you reach the new key. Finally, look for a logical pivot point. Sometimes two successive chords could logically be pivot chords. If so, include two chords on either side of your pivot bracket.

section.p: Before we start analyzing and writing modulations, we will examine key relationships and pivot chords.

section.title: Key Relationships
section.p: In the Baroque and Classical eras, composers typically modulated to the dominant (when starting in a major key) or to the relative major (when starting in a minor key). In the Romantic era, composers experimented with modulating to more remote (or perhaps adventurous) key areas, described as foreign to the home key.

Closely related keysclosely related keysdefinition of have key signatures one degree sharper or flatter than the starting key. For any major or minor key, there are five closely related keys, including the relative major or minor of the home key.

figure.caption: Closely Related Keys with A Major as Home Key

section.p: Key signatures that are not closely related are said to be foreignforeign keys or distantly relateddistantly related keys. We will see that some types of modulations from the Romantic era, like commontone modulations, exploit foreign key relationships to dramatic effect.

introduction.p: Modulations with pivot chords will be analyzed using a pivot bracket, as we've seen earlier in the chapter.
In a diatonic common chord modulationdiatonic common chord modulationmodulationdiatonic common chord, the pivot chords will be diatonic in both keys.

subsection.title: Determining Common Chords Between Keys
subsection.p: In order to compose a diatonic common chord modulation, you need to determine which chords are diatonichaving the same root and qualityin both keys.

figure.caption: Diatonic Common Chords in G major and D major

subsection.p: We can repeat this process with Roman numerals, aligning the roots of the chords in the two keys.

figure.caption: Roman Numerals for Diatonic Common Chords in G major and D major

subsection.p: If you are a composer wanting to write a diatonic common chord modulation, you need to determine the best place within a progression to pivot to the new key. To do this, you need to consider the harmonic function of the pivot chords.

subsection.title: Harmonic Functions of Diatonic Pivot Chords
subsection.p: In terms of harmonic function, composers typically do not use a pivot chord that has dominant function in the new key because such a modulation might sound abrupt and unconvincing. Instead, the pivot chord in the first key often has tonic or tonic prolongation function.

In the following example, the pivot chord simultaneously has tonic function in the first key and predominant function in the second key. This creates a more seamless and less jarring progression to the second key.

figure.caption: J.S. Bach, Christmas Oratorio, BWV 248, Ermuntre dich, mein schwacher Geist, (Chorale) (1734)

idx.h: English Suite No. 4 in F Major, BWV 809, Sarabande

subsection.p: The pivot chord in the first key, G, has tonic harmonic function, while in the second key, D major, the G chord has predominant function.

section.title: How to Recognize a Key After a Modulation
section.p: Look for the following cues when examining music containing modulations:

li.p:
Look for recurring accidentals, then add them to the key signature to determine the new key
Lowered notes (like flats) usually create 4 (as do the flats in key signatures)
Raised notes (like sharps) often create 7, the leading tone
If there are multiple raised notes, look for the sharpest of sharps (in key signature order) to determine which sharp is acting as 7
If accidentals are canceled out, they indicate tonicizations or chromatic nonchord tones

figure.caption: J.S. Bach, English Suite No. 4 in F Major, BWV 809, Sarabande (ca. 1715)

idx.h: English Suite No. 4 in F Major, BWV 809, Sarabande

subsection.title: Borrowed Common Chord
subsection.p: In modulation by borrowed common chordmodulationborrowed common chord (or mode mixture), the pivot chord will be a borrowed chord in one of the keys involved in the modulation.
In the following example, a borrowed chord, in D minor, rewritten as a C minor chord, is reinterpreted as in the second key, E major.

subsection.p: A particularly adventurous and imaginative pivot is the NeapolitanmodulationNeapolitan common chord, which can bridge the gap between two foreign (or distantly related) keys.

subsection.title: Augmented Sixth Common Chord
subsection.p: In the next chapter, we will examine how Augmented Sixth chords are enharmonically reinterpreted in a process known as enharmonic modulation.

subsection.title: Direct Modulation

introduction.p: Direct modulationdirect modulationmodulationdirect (also known as phrase modulation) is a type of modulation where a composer decides to move suddenly to a new key without using pivot chords or preparing the new tonic with its dominant.

figure.caption: Schubert, Schwanegesang, D. 957, Liebesbotschaft (1828)

subsection.p: In the example below from the second song of the same song cycle as the example above, Schubert does not attempt to change gradually from C minor to A major, but instead stops on a half cadence in C minor and begins on the tonic in A major in the next bar.

figure.caption: Schubert, Schwanegesang, D. 957, Kriegers Ahnung (1828)

subsection.p: Direct modulation is the most common type of modulation found in popular music. At the beginning of this chapter we defined this type of modulation in popular music as key change.

figure.caption: James Horner and Will Jennings, My Heart Will Go On (1997)

idx.h: My Heart Will Go On (from Titanic)

subsection.p: With direct modulation, composers do not make any attempt to connect two different keys through any pivot chords or common tones. In the next section, we examine how composers connect two keys through a common tone.

introduction.p: In commontone modulationcommontone modulationmodulationcommontone, two chords are connected through a single note to bridge to distance between two keys.
In the following example, the note C acts as a hinge between a C major chord ( in F minor) and an A dominant seventh chord ( in D major).

conclusion.p: In the next example, the note A acts as a hinge between an A major chord ( in D minor) and an F major chord ( in F major).

subsubsection.title: Chromatic Mediants

introduction.p: In a commontone modulation, the two chords connecting the two keys are typically in a chromatic mediant relationship. Chromatic mediantschromatic mediants are chords with roots a third apart that share only one common tone and have the same quality (both are major or both are minor).

subsection.title: Sequential Modulation

introduction.p: Modulation can also be accomplished by sequence. In a sequential modulationsequential modulationmodulationsequential, a melody and its accompanying harmonies are repeated at a new pitch level to establish or lead to a new key. In the following example, the sequence of the original idea occurs in the new key.

figure.caption: Beethoven, Piano Sonata Op. 2, No. 1, III. (1795)

subsection.p: In the following example, an idea in C major is repeated up a step in D major, then up another step in E minor before reaching an F chord, a chord with dominant function in G major.

figure.caption: Mozart, Oboe Concerto in C major, K. 314, III. (1777)

idx.h: Oboe Concerto in C major, K. 314, III.

subsection.p: In the next example, after a cadence in G minor, an idea in F minor is repeated down a whole step in E minor to achieve the change of key to E major, which is the starting key of this aria, as can be seen in the key signature.
